title: General Mills Reports Earnings Tomorrow. Here’s What to Expect.
text:
Text size

Shares of food maker General Mills (ticker: GIS) are up some 40% this year, about double that of the S&P 500. The company’s signature brands include Betty Crocker, Haagen-Dazs ice cream, and Cheerios.

Its cereal products have performed well in the U.S. and helped boost the stock, according to a recent research note by Guggenheim, which also said the company’s yogurt business is stabilizing.

But when the company releases its fiscal first-quarter earnings before the opening bell on Wednesday, investors will be paying close attention to one of its newest brands—natural-pet-food maker Blue Buffalo.

FactSet’s consensus first-quarter profit estimate for the company is 77 cents a share, up from 71 cents in the corresponding period a year ago.

A key metric will be the company’s organic sales growth, to which Blue Buffalo is expected to be a big contributor. General Mills acquired Blue Buffalo last year for about $8 billion.

In the company’s fiscal fourth quarter, the pet segment’s revenue totaled just over $400 million, or about 10% of the company’s total sales.

The Street is looking for the company’s first-quarter organic sales to increase 0.7%, according to JPMorgan, though the company’s own analysts are expecting a 0.2% boost.

Guggenheim, however, forecasts an increase of 0.8%, helped by the Blue Buffalo line that “is gaining distribution outside the pet specialty channel.” It expects that business to help support upward earnings revisions throughout the year. Organic sales disappointed the market in the fiscal fourth quarter.

The FactSet consensus estimate for this fiscal year, which ends next May, is $3.35 a share, up from $3.22 in the previous year. The stock yields 3.6%.

Investors also will be keeping tabs on a series of management changes announced last month. That includes a succession plan for the current chief financial officer.
